name: Product Knowledge Rubric
description: Evaluates technical accuracy, competitive positioning, and ability to connect features to business value

scoring_guide.90-100: Expert-level product knowledge - technically accurate, strong competitive positioning, clear value articulation
scoring_guide.80-89: Strong product knowledge - mostly accurate with minor gaps, good value connection
scoring_guide.70-79: Adequate product knowledge - generally correct but misses opportunities or lacks depth
scoring_guide.60-69: Weak product knowledge - some inaccuracies or unclear explanations
scoring_guide.0-59: Poor product knowledge - significant inaccuracies or inability to explain capabilities

technical_accuracy.description: Correctness of technical statements about product capabilities

excellent: Accurately describes product architecture and capabilities
Provides accurate examples of use cases

feature_to_value_connection.description: Ability to connect features to business outcomes

excellent: Explains features in terms of customer problems they solve
poor: Focuses on 'how it works' vs. 'what you achieve'
Generic value props not tailored to customer

competitive_positioning.description: Accuracy and effectiveness of competitive differentiation

excellent: Accurately positions vs. Airflow, Temporal, Dagster
Highlights genuine differentiators relevant to customer
Reframes competitive concerns as our advantages

use_case_relevance.description: Provides relevant examples and use cases

excellent: Tailors examples to customer's industry/tech stack
poor: Generic examples not relevant to customer
Unclear or confusing use case explanations

common_competitive_comparisons.vs_airflow: No scheduler headaches, local testing with pytest, dynamic workflows, modern Python
common_competitive_comparisons.vs_temporal: Higher-level for data workflows, easier learning curve, better observability out-of-box
common_competitive_comparisons.vs_dagster: Lighter weight, don't need asset definitions everywhere, simpler mental model

key_differentiators: Managed Prefect with zero ops burden
Advanced access controls and audit logs
pricing_positioning: Includes cost of engineering time saved on ops

strong_product_knowledge.quote: Unlike Airflow where you define static DAGs, Prefect workflows are dynamic Python functions. This means you can use if/else logic, loops, and even generate tasks at runtime based on data. For your use case of processing varying numbers of files, you wouldn't need to create a task per file upfront - Prefect handles that dynamically.
strong_product_knowledge.analysis: Technically accurate comparison, explains feature (dynamic workflows) in context of customer's specific need (varying file counts), contrasts with competitor limitation.

weak_product_knowledge.quote: Prefect is better than Airflow because it's newer and has a nicer UI.
weak_product_knowledge.analysis: Vague, subjective differentiation without technical substance. Doesn't connect to business value or customer needs.
